Packed with plant protein, these sticky miso tofu bowls with peas, edamame and ginger are nourishing, flavoursome and super easy to make. Thanks @deliciouslyella. 

IngredientsÂ 
2 servings of basmati rice, (about 100g / 3.5 oz) rinsedÂ 
1 tablespoon olive oilÂ 
Small chunk of ginger, (about 20g / 0.7 oz) cut into matchsticks/gratedÂ 
2 large cloves garlic, thinly slicedÂ 
1 tablespoon tamariÂ 
100g / Â¾ cup / 3.5 oz frozen peas, defrostedÂ 
100g / Â¾ cup / 3.5 oz frozen edamame beans, defrostedÂ 
Pinch of sea salt 

For the sticky tofuÂ 
1 tablespoon olive oilÂ 
1 block firm smoked tofu, (about 280g / 10 oz) drained & cut into bite-sized piecesÂ 
1 tablespoon tamariÂ 
2 tablespoons maple syrupÂ 
2 tablespoons brown rice miso pasteÂ 
2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar 

MethodÂ  

Pour the rice into a small saucepan, along with 200ml / 7 fl oz water and a large pinch of salt. Bring to the boil, then cover with a lid, reduce the heat to low and simmer for 10 minutes until all of the water has been absorbed. Remove from the heat and set aside.Â 
Â 
While the rice is cooking, warm 1 tablespoon of oil in a large frying pan set over mediumâ€“high heat. Add the tofu and cook for 10 minutes, stirring often, until crisp and golden on all sides.Â 
Â 
Next, whisk together 1 tablespoon tamari, the maple syrup, miso paste and rice wine vinegar. Once the tofu is cooked, pour the sauce into the pan and let it reduce to create a sticky sauce that coats the tofu. Remove the tofu from the pan and set aside on a plate.Â 
Â 
Pour 1 tablespoon of olive oil into the same pan, followed by the cooked rice, ginger and garlic. Fry for 5 minutes, until crisp, then stir in the tamari, peas, edamame beans and crispy tofu. Divide between 2 bowls and serve with your favourite crispy chilli oil/sauce.

Iâ€™m making this on repeat at the moment, so wanted to share the recipe with you. Itâ€™s a family favourite, such a good staple and one of the easiest ways to up your veggie intake. Itâ€™s a nice one for food waste too, simply swap the veg for anything youâ€™ve got lying around at home - leeks, whole tomatoes, courgettes, leafy greens etc are all delicious additions, likewise white beans instead of chickpeas and any pasta shape instead of orecchiette (broken pieces of lasagne are fab, as is orzo). Dial the chilli up or down to taste, or simply add it at the end if youâ€™re making this for little ones (once youâ€™ve served them) 

For the nourishing veggie broth with orecchiette, youâ€™ll need 
- 2 tablespoons olive oil
- 1 large onion, thinly sliced
- 2 carrots, halved lengthways & cut into 1cm half moons
- 2 sticks of celery, finely chopped
- 4 cloves garlic, crushed/finely chopped
- 2 bay leaves
- small handful of thyme sprigs
- 1 tablespoon tomato purÃ©e
- 1 tablespoon brown rice miso paste
- 1 x 400g tin chopped tomatoes
- 1 x 400g tin chickpeas, drained
- 1Â¼ litre vegetable stock
- 3 servings of orecchiette (about 225g)
- large handful of basil
- pinch of dried red chilli flakes
- pinch of sea salt

1. Warm the olive oil in a large deep saucepan or casserole dish set over medium heat. Add the onion, carrots, celery, garlic, a pinch of salt and cook for 5 minutes until slightly softened.

2. Stir in the bay leaves, thyme leaves, tomato purÃ©e and miso; cook for 2â€“3 minutes until fragrant. 

3. Next, pour in the tinned tomatoes, chickpeas and stock. Bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 10â€“15 minutes until the vegetables are tender. 

4. Remove the pan from the heat and use a hand blender to roughly blitz half of the soup to thicken it slightly (if you like), then return to the heat, add the pasta and cook for 8â€“10 minutes until al dente. 

5. Divide between bowls and scatter over the basil, chilli flakes (if using) and a drizzle of olive oil

The recipe is from our website/app alongside 1,000+ other delicious, plant-based recipes: https://www.deliciouslyella.com/recipes/nourishing-veggie-broth-with-orecchiette/

10 simple, delicious recipes to try this weekend ğŸŒ±

1. Chickpea, tomato & avocado toastie. Inspired by a tuna mayo concept, this is a super easy, quick (but delicious!) bite. 
2. Nutty sweet potato & quinoa salad with crunchy almonds and an extra creamy almond butter and tahini dressing.
3. Creamy broccoli pasta bake. With four different green veggies in it, this is an easy way to pack goodness into your life!
4. Pan-fried tomato hummus. Ready in 15-mins, this is so so good! 
5. Roasted cauliflower with butter bean mash. Surprisingly easy to make with less than 10 ingredients, full of fibre and so delicious! Butter bean mash is such a great way to get more beans in your life, if you havenâ€™t tried it yet then really recommend. 
6. Nourishing veggie broth with orecchiette. Such a great weekly staple, packed with veggies and so nourishing. 
7. Coconut custard & berries toast. With just 6 ingredients, itâ€™s a super easy brunch - almost the worlds easiest french toast! 
8. Storecupboard tofu & tomato curry. Filled with plant-protein, this is a one pan wonder that makes for great leftovers. 
9. Creamy kale & sweet potato salad. A favourite for over 10 years now! Itâ€™s the salad that keeps on giving 
10. Balsamic roasted barley & tomato risotto. A healthier twist on a classic risotto, using barley instead of rice. This is on our menu for the weekend!
